title: Biden Judicial Nominees Testify in Senate Panel Hearing
sub_head: Diversity is a focus as committee considers two Black women tapped for appeals court positions
body:
WASHINGTON—Racial and professional diversity in the federal judiciary were central topics during a Senate hearing Wednesday for five of President Biden’s judicial nominees, including one who could eventually be a candidate for the Supreme Court.
The Senate Judiciary Committee, holding its first judicial confirmation hearing since Mr. Biden took office, heard from two nominees for federal appeals roles: Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson, nominated for a prominent appeals court in Washington; and lawyer Candace Jackson-Akiwumi, tapped for a seat on the Chicago-based Seventh U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals.
If confirmed, Judge Jackson would replace Attorney General Merrick Garland on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
The committee also heard from three nominees for U.S. district courts, the trial courts in the federal system, including Zahid Quraishi, who would become the first Muslim-American to hold such a post. All five nominees are people of color, reflecting Mr. Biden’s pledge to diversify the federal bench.
Much of the hearing focused on Judge Jackson and Ms. Jackson-Akiwumi, both Black women who have experience as federal public defenders representing indigent criminal defendants.
